articles.headline: Complaining Correctly Can Pay Off
articles.snippet: Damon Darlin Your Money column on slow change in attitude of call center representatives toward customers seeking to rectify problems; companies are now embracing idea that happy customers tend to buy more products or recommend company's product o...
articles.abstract: Damon Darlin Your Money column on slow change in attitude of call center representatives toward customers seeking to rectify problems; companies are now embracing idea that happy customers tend to buy more products or recommend company's product or service to others; call center managers and supervisors offer advice on how customers can get what they want; photos (M)
articles.lead_paragraph: I WANT to speak to a supervisor."

articles.headline: Rocky Return to the Roots at Wal-Mart
articles.snippet: Dismissal of marketing team head Julie Roehm, for allegedly violating company policy by accepting gifts from potential vendors and maintaining personal relationship with subordinate, exposes deeper tensions within Wal-Mart empire; company, which y...
articles.abstract: Dismissal of marketing team head Julie Roehm, for allegedly violating company policy by accepting gifts from potential vendors and maintaining personal relationship with subordinate, exposes deeper tensions within Wal-Mart empire; company, which year ago introduced ads that emphasized style and played down price as it tried to appeal to more affluent Americans, has suddenly reversed itself and has begun trumpeting price-slashing for 2006 holiday season (M)
articles.lead_paragraph: It was the kind of bold advertising campaign that Wal-Mart executives agreed was needed to attract style-hungry consumers: a series of commercials featuring two sisters -- one a regular Wal-Mart shopper, the other not -- trying to redecorate their homes.
articles.byline: By Michael Barbaro and Stuart Elliott

articles.headline: Poachers in West Hunt Big Antlers to Feed Big Egos
articles.snippet: Elk, deer and other big-game animals are being killed in wave of poaching that has alarmed state and federal wildlife officials in Nevada and several other Western states; authorities say they are seeing more organized rings of poachers and unlice...
articles.abstract: Elk, deer and other big-game animals are being killed in wave of poaching that has alarmed state and federal wildlife officials in Nevada and several other Western states; authorities say they are seeing more organized rings of poachers and unlicensed guides chasing biggest elk and mule deer, with largest antler array, sometimes trading them on Internet auction sites or submitting pictures to hunting magazines that prominently feature big kills; National Park Service says that poaching contributed to decline of 29 species of wildlife in 390 parks and other sites it oversees; map; photos (M)
articles.lead_paragraph: ELY, Nev., Dec. 3 - A bighorn sheep lay in a field not far from here, its head missing. In nearby Elko, three elk and five deer died from gunshot wounds, their carcasses rotting in the hills. And in the distant mountains, game wardens searched for another elk that a tipster said had been killed by illegal hunters apparently just for the thrill of it.

articles.headline: Looking for a Gambit to Win at Google’s Game
articles.snippet: Article on efforts by Microsoft to compete with Google in Internet business; Microsoft's online properties have lost users in US over last year and billions of dollars it has spent to build its own search engine have yet to pay off; Steve Berkowit...
articles.abstract: Article on efforts by Microsoft to compete with Google in Internet business; Microsoft's online properties have lost users in US over last year and billions of dollars it has spent to build its own search engine have yet to pay off; Steve Berkowitz, who heads Microsoft's online services unit, comments on changes that have been made and those that are planned; photos; graphs (M)
articles.lead_paragraph: There is a lot about the way Microsoft has run its Internet business that Steve Berkowitz wants to change. But he is finding that redirecting such a behemoth is slow going.

articles.headline: Billions Later, Plan to Remake the Coast Guard Fleet Stumbles
articles.snippet: First of two articles notes that four years after Coast Guard began effort to replace nearly its entire fleet of ships, planes and helicopters, modernization program heralded as model of government innovation is foundering; problems have helped sw...
articles.abstract: First of two articles notes that four years after Coast Guard began effort to replace nearly its entire fleet of ships, planes and helicopters, modernization program heralded as model of government innovation is foundering; problems have helped swell costs of program, called Deepwater, to projected $24 billion, from $17 billion; Coast Guard hired Lockheed Martin and Northrop Grumman to plan, supervise and deliver new vessels and helicopters; many retired Coast Guard officials and government auditors fault privatization effort; program's few Congressional skeptics were outmatched by enthusiastic lawmakers mobilized by aggressive lobbying campaign financed by Lockheed and Northrop; Deepwater joins long list of troubled programs for Homeland Security Dept, which took over responsibility for Coast Guard in 2003; photos (L)
articles.lead_paragraph: Correction Appended

articles.headline: Poachers in West Hunt Big Antlers to Feed Big Egos
articles.snippet: A wave of poaching has alarmed state and federal wildlife officials in several Western states.
articles.abstract: A wave of poaching has alarmed state and federal wildlife officials in several Western states.
articles.lead_paragraph: ELY, Nev., Dec. 3 — A bighorn sheep lay in a field not far from here, its head missing. In nearby Elko, three elk and five deer died from gunshot wounds, their carcasses rotting in the hills. And in the distant mountains, game wardens searched for another elk that a tipster said had been killed by illegal hunters apparently just for the thrill of it.

articles.headline: Iraqis Line Up to Put Hussein in the Noose
articles.snippet: Hundreds of people have already started lobbying to become the executioner for Saddam Hussein.
articles.abstract: Hundreds of people have already started lobbying to become the executioner for Saddam Hussein.
articles.lead_paragraph: BAGHDAD, Dec. 8 — One of the most coveted jobs in Iraq does not yet exist: the executioner for Saddam Hussein. The death sentence against Mr. Hussein is still under review by an appeals court, but hundreds of people have already started lobbying the prime minister’s office for the position.

articles.headline: Heavy Day of Trading in 2 Banks
articles.snippet: Talk of possible major changes at Citigroup and Bank of America set off heavy trading in the shares of the two banking giants.
articles.abstract: Talk of possible major changes at Citigroup and Bank of America set off heavy trading in the shares of the two banking giants.
articles.lead_paragraph: Wall Street trembled yesterday with talk of possible major changes at Citigroup and Bank of America, setting off heavy trading in the shares of the two banking giants.
articles.byline: By Eric Dash and Heather Timmons

articles.headline: China, Shy Giant, Shows Signs of Shedding Its False Modesty
articles.snippet: China's Communist Party has new agenda: it is encouraging people to discuss what it means to be major world power and has largely stopped denying that China intends to become one soon; its tradition of modesty has begun to fade, replaced by growin...
articles.abstract: China's Communist Party has new agenda: it is encouraging people to discuss what it means to be major world power and has largely stopped denying that China intends to become one soon; its tradition of modesty has begun to fade, replaced by growing confidence that China's rise is not fleeting and that country needs to do more to define its objectives; Beijing has begun asserting its interests far beyond its borders, with $1 trillion in foreign exchange reserves, surging military spending and diplomatic initiatives in Asia, Africa, and Middle East; China's main television network has broadcast 12-part documentary describing reasons nine nations rose to become great powers; photos (M)
articles.lead_paragraph: BEIJING, Dec. 8 - China's Communist Party has a new agenda: it is encouraging people to discuss what it means to be a major world power and has largely stopped denying that China intends to become one soon.

articles.headline: Iraqis Near Deal on Distribution of Oil Revenues
articles.snippet: Iraqi officials are near agreement on national oil law that would give central government power to distribute oil revenues to provinces or regions, based on their populations; measure could help resolve divisive issue that has blocked efforts to r...
articles.abstract: Iraqi officials are near agreement on national oil law that would give central government power to distribute oil revenues to provinces or regions, based on their populations; measure could help resolve divisive issue that has blocked efforts to reconcile country's feuding ethnic and sectarian factions; Sunni Arabs, who lead insurgency, have opposed idea of regional autonomy for fear that they would be deprived of fair share of country's oil wealth, which is concentrated in Shiite south and Kurdish north; Iraq Study Group report stressed that oil law guaranteeing equitable distribution of revenues was crucial to process of national reconciliation, and to ending war; photo (M)
articles.lead_paragraph: BAGHDAD, Dec. 8 - Iraqi officials are near agreement on a national oil law that would give the central government the power to distribute current and future oil revenues to the provinces or regions, based on their population, Iraqi and American officials say.

articles.headline: Looking for a Gambit to Win at Google’s Game
articles.snippet: Microsoft’s online chief wants to change the way his company runs its Internet business.  But he is finding that redirecting such a behemoth is slow going.
articles.abstract: Microsoft’s online chief wants to change the way his company runs its Internet business.  But he is finding that redirecting such a behemoth is slow going.
articles.lead_paragraph: There is a lot about the way Microsoft has run its Internet business that Steve Berkowitz wants to change. But he is finding that redirecting such a behemoth is slow going.

articles.headline: Iraqis Line Up to Put Hussein in the Noose
articles.snippet: One of most coveted jobs in Iraq does not yet exist: executioner for Saddam Hussein; death sentence against Hussein is under review by appeals court, but hundreds of people have started lobbying prime minister's office for position; Hussein and tw...
articles.abstract: One of most coveted jobs in Iraq does not yet exist: executioner for Saddam Hussein; death sentence against Hussein is under review by appeals court, but hundreds of people have started lobbying prime minister's office for position; Hussein and two of his top associates, Barzan Ibrahim al-Tikriti and Awad al-Bandar, were sentenced to 'death by hanging' on Nov 5 for their involvement in killings of 148 men and boys after assassination attempt against him in Dujail in 1982; Hussein's execution must be carried out within 30 days if appeals court upholds death sentence; photo (M)
articles.lead_paragraph: BAGHDAD, Dec. 8 - One of the most coveted jobs in Iraq does not yet exist: the executioner for Saddam Hussein. The death sentence against Mr. Hussein is still under review by an appeals court, but hundreds of people have already started lobbying the prime minister's office for the position.

articles.headline: Democrats Plan Oil Royalties Inquiry
articles.snippet: House Democratic leaders, after defeat of measure that would have pressured oil companies to give up legal loop hole that is expected to allow them to avoid as much as $10 billion in royalties over next five years, vow to pursue broad overhaul of ...
articles.abstract: House Democratic leaders, after defeat of measure that would have pressured oil companies to give up legal loop hole that is expected to allow them to avoid as much as $10 billion in royalties over next five years, vow to pursue broad overhaul of tax breaks and other subsidies to oil companies; says first step will be investigation of how government collects billions of dollars in royalties on oil and gas produced on federal property; incoming House Resources Committee chairman Nick Rahall says he plans sweeping probe of Interior Department's enforcement of royalty payments and possible repeal of law that allows energy companies drilling in deep coastal waters to avoid billions of dollars in payments; photos (M)
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, Dec. 8 - House Democratic leaders vowed Friday to pursue a broad overhaul of tax breaks and other subsidies to oil companies in January, saying that their first target would be an investigation of how the government collects billions of dollars in royalties on oil and gas produced on federal property.

articles.headline: Democrats Plan Oil Royalties Inquiry
articles.snippet: House Democrats vowed to pursue a broad overhaul of tax breaks and other subsidies to oil companies in January.
articles.abstract: House Democrats vowed to pursue a broad overhaul of tax breaks and other subsidies to oil companies in January.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, Dec. 8 — House Democratic leaders vowed Friday to pursue a broad overhaul of tax breaks and other subsidies to oil companies in January, saying that their first target would be an investigation of how the government collects billions of dollars in royalties on oil and gas produced on federal property.

articles.headline: China, Shy Giant, Shows Signs of Shedding Its False Modesty
articles.snippet: China is discussing what it means to be a world power and has largely stopped denying that it intends to become one.
articles.abstract: China is discussing what it means to be a world power and has largely stopped denying that it intends to become one.
articles.lead_paragraph: BEIJING, Dec. 8 — China’s Communist Party has a new agenda: it is encouraging people to discuss what it means to be a major world power and has largely stopped denying that China intends to become one soon.

articles.headline: Iraqis Near Deal on Distribution of Oil Revenues
articles.snippet: The law would allow the central government to distribute oil revenues to the provinces based on their population.
articles.abstract: The law would allow the central government to distribute oil revenues to the provinces based on their population.
articles.lead_paragraph: BAGHDAD, Dec. 8 — Iraqi officials are near agreement on a national oil law that would give the central government the power to distribute current and future oil revenues to the provinces or regions, based on their population, Iraqi and American officials say.

articles.headline: Billions Later, Plan to Remake the Coast Guard Fleet Stumbles
articles.snippet: An initial venture has been canceled after hull cracks and engine failures made the first eight boats unseaworthy.
articles.abstract: An initial venture has been canceled after hull cracks and engine failures made the first eight boats unseaworthy.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, Dec. 8 — Four years after the Coast Guard began an effort to replace nearly its entire fleet of ships, planes and helicopters, the modernization program heralded as a model of government innovation is foundering.

articles.headline: Complaining Correctly Can Pay Off
articles.snippet: Some advice from call center managers and supervisors on the best methods for getting what you want.
articles.abstract: Some advice from call center managers and supervisors on the best methods for getting what you want.
articles.lead_paragraph: I WANT to speak to a supervisor.”

articles.headline: Heavy Day of Trading in 2 Banks
articles.snippet: Talk of possible major changes at Citigroup and Bank of America spurs heavy trading in shares of both banks; shares of Citigroup rise 2.25 percent, biggest daily gain since April; Bank of America shares fall 1.6 percent (M)
articles.abstract: Talk of possible major changes at Citigroup and Bank of America spurs heavy trading in shares of both banks; shares of Citigroup rise 2.25 percent, biggest daily gain since April; Bank of America shares fall 1.6 percent (M)
articles.lead_paragraph: Correction Appended
articles.byline: By Eric Dash and Heather Timmons

articles.headline: Rocky Return to the Roots at Wal-Mart
articles.snippet: Julie Roehm’s downfall exposes deeper tensions within the Wal-Mart empire, as the company tries to appeal to more affluent Americans.
articles.abstract: Julie Roehm’s downfall exposes deeper tensions within the Wal-Mart empire, as the company tries to appeal to more affluent Americans.
articles.lead_paragraph: It was the kind of bold advertising campaign that Wal-Mart executives agreed was needed to attract style-hungry consumers: a series of commercials featuring two sisters  one a regular Wal-Mart shopper, the other not  trying to redecorate their homes.
articles.byline: By Michael Barbaro and Stuart Elliott

articles.headline: Report on Iraq Exposes a Divide Within the G.O.P.
articles.snippet: Fissures over Iraq could make it more difficult for Republicans to coalesce on national security policy and avoid a bitter intraparty fight going into 2008.
articles.abstract: Fissures over Iraq could make it more difficult for Republicans to coalesce on national security policy and avoid a bitter intraparty fight going into 2008.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, Dec. 9 — The release of the report by the bipartisan Iraq Study Group this week exposed deep fissures among Republicans over how to manage a war that many fear will haunt their party — and the nation — for years to come.
articles.byline: By John M. Broder and Robin Toner

articles.headline: Black-Market Weapon Prices Surge in Iraq Chaos
articles.snippet: Weapon prices are soaring in Iraq amid sectarian strife as more buyers push prices several times higher than those that existed at time of American-led invasion; rising prices encourage migration of army and police weapons from Iraqi state armorie...
articles.abstract: Weapon prices are soaring in Iraq amid sectarian strife as more buyers push prices several times higher than those that existed at time of American-led invasion; rising prices encourage migration of army and police weapons from Iraqi state armories to black-market sales; American-issue weapons are also on sale in shops and bazaars, purchased by United States for Iraqi forces; photo; map (L)
articles.lead_paragraph: SULAIMANIYA, Iraq, Dec. 8 - The Kurdish security contractor placed the black plastic box on the table. Inside was a new Glock 19, one of the 9-millimeter pistols that the United States issued by the tens of thousands to the Iraqi Army and police.

articles.headline: DNA Gatherers Hit Snag: Tribes Don’t Trust Them
articles.snippet: At issue is whether scientists seeking DNA from aboriginal populations are underselling the risks to donors.
articles.abstract: At issue is whether scientists seeking DNA from aboriginal populations are underselling the risks to donors.
articles.lead_paragraph: SOUTH NAKNEK, Alaska — The National Geographic Society’s multimillion-dollar research project to collect DNA from indigenous groups around the world in the hopes of reconstructing humanity’s ancient migrations has come to a standstill on its home turf in North America.

articles.headline: Religion for Captive Audiences, With Taxpayers Footing the Bill
articles.snippet: Article in series In God's Name; Federal Judge Robert W Pratt ruled in June that Iowa prison program that offered prisoners amenities in exchange for entering intensely religious rehabilitation program monitored by evangelical Christians was uncon...
articles.abstract: Article in series In God's Name; Federal Judge Robert W Pratt ruled in June that Iowa prison program that offered prisoners amenities in exchange for entering intensely religious rehabilitation program monitored by evangelical Christians was unconstitutional use of taxpayer money; ordered $1.5 million of federal money repaid; courts have cited more than dozen similar programs since 2000, but programs are proliferating; government agencies have been repeatedly cited for not doing enough to guard against taxpayer-funded evangelism, but improperly used money is typically not repaid; photos; chart (L)
articles.lead_paragraph: Correction Appended
articles.byline: By Diana B. Henriques and Andrew Lehren

articles.headline: DNA Gatherers Hit Snag: Tribes Don’t Trust Them
articles.snippet: National Geographic Society's multi-million-dollar Genographic Project to collect 100,000 DNA samples from indigenous people in effort to reconstruct humanity's ancient migrations stalls after Alaska Area Institutional Review Board suggests to Ala...
articles.abstract: National Geographic Society's multi-million-dollar Genographic Project to collect 100,000 DNA samples from indigenous people in effort to reconstruct humanity's ancient migrations stalls after Alaska Area Institutional Review Board suggests to Alaska natives that project could threaten world-view that some indigenous leaders see as crucial to preserving their culture; officials with project say it is paternalistic to imply that indigenous groups need to be kept from knowledge that genetics might offer; Indians fear scientific evidence could chip away at their collective legal rights; maps; diagrams; photo (L)
articles.lead_paragraph: Correction Appended

articles.headline: Poisoned by Scandal, Craving an Antidote
articles.snippet: Article on scandal that led to demise of Rent-Way, which was bought in November by its biggest rival Rent-A-Center; William Morgenstern, former Rent-Way chairman and chief executive, comments on his efforts to save company after he revealed accoun...
articles.abstract: Article on scandal that led to demise of Rent-Way, which was bought in November by its biggest rival Rent-A-Center; William Morgenstern, former Rent-Way chairman and chief executive, comments on his efforts to save company after he revealed accounting fraud in 2000; photo (M)
articles.lead_paragraph: NEAR midnight on a Friday in 2000, William E. Morgenstern, the chief executive of Rent-Way, one of the nation's largest rent-to-own retailers, was preparing for bed when a woman called to warn him that the company he had built from scratch was about to fall apart.

articles.headline: Yes, You Can Surf in Cleveland, Before the Brown Water Freezes
articles.snippet: Cleveland surfers have Lake Erie almost entirely to themselves in winter, when storm winds push chocolate-colored waves 10 feet high before crashing onto beach of boulders and logs; many of roughly 25 committed surfers in Cleveland work nights all...
articles.abstract: Cleveland surfers have Lake Erie almost entirely to themselves in winter, when storm winds push chocolate-colored waves 10 feet high before crashing onto beach of boulders and logs; many of roughly 25 committed surfers in Cleveland work nights all year round to keep their winter days free for surfing; surfers watch friends for signs of hypothermia; photo (L)
articles.lead_paragraph: CLEVELAND, Dec. 9 - They surf in Cleveland because they must. They surf with two-inch icicles clinging to their wet suits, through stinging hail and overpowering wind. They work nights to spend their winter days scouting surf. They are watermen on an inland sea.

articles.headline: A House Divided: Uncivil War on E. 73rd
articles.snippet: Article details longstanding and acrimonious feud between George Pavia, owner of elegant Manhattan brownstone on East 73rd Street, and tenant James Couri; Pavia has accused Couri of engaging in various forms of 'nuisance' behavior, which he conten...
articles.abstract: Article details longstanding and acrimonious feud between George Pavia, owner of elegant Manhattan brownstone on East 73rd Street, and tenant James Couri; Pavia has accused Couri of engaging in various forms of 'nuisance' behavior, which he contends undermines his family's and other tenants' rights to peaceful habitation; Couri has countersued, contending Pavia failed to disclose rent-stabilized status of building; latest dispute is scheduled to be heard in New York State Supreme Court in February; photos (L)
articles.lead_paragraph: SAVORING the imminent arrival of a long-awaited day in court, George M. Pavia relaxed with his family in their elegant Manhattan brownstone, munching on cheese and crackers. Mr. Pavia, 78, a senior partner at Pavia & Harcourt, a corporate law firm with offices in New York and Milan, waxed poetic about his snack. "Good smelly French cheese!" he proclaimed to his wife. "I love it!"

articles.headline: A House Divided: Uncivil War on E. 73rd
articles.snippet: A feud worthy of the Hatfields and the McCoys — a standoff that has involved housing inspectors, police officers and private investigators, not to mention whopping legal fees.
articles.abstract: A feud worthy of the Hatfields and the McCoys — a standoff that has involved housing inspectors, police officers and private investigators, not to mention whopping legal fees.
articles.lead_paragraph: SAVORING the imminent arrival of a long-awaited day in court, George M. Pavia relaxed with his family in their elegant Manhattan brownstone, munching on cheese and crackers. Mr. Pavia, 78, a senior partner at Pavia & Harcourt, a corporate law firm with offices in New York and Milan, waxed poetic about his snack. “Good smelly French cheese!” he proclaimed to his wife. “I love it!”

articles.headline: Trading Up to Careers in the Operating Room
articles.snippet: Montefiore Medical Center in Bronx urges less-skilled workers to train as surgical technologists under program provided by Health Care Institute of nonprofit Consortium for Worker Education; United Healthcare Workers East union helps pay for cours...
articles.abstract: Montefiore Medical Center in Bronx urges less-skilled workers to train as surgical technologists under program provided by Health Care Institute of nonprofit Consortium for Worker Education; United Healthcare Workers East union helps pay for courses; photo (M)
articles.lead_paragraph: AFTER seven years as a secretary in the psychiatry department at Montefiore Medical Center in the Bronx, India Rouault said, she was "tired of pushing papers." She also welcomed the prospect of earning more money.

articles.headline: Yes, You Can Surf in Cleveland, Before the Brown Water Freezes
articles.snippet: In December, as temperatures dip into the 20s, Cleveland surfers have Lake Erie almost entirely to themselves.
articles.abstract: In December, as temperatures dip into the 20s, Cleveland surfers have Lake Erie almost entirely to themselves.
articles.lead_paragraph: CLEVELAND, Dec. 9 — They surf in Cleveland because they must. They surf with two-inch icicles clinging to their wet suits, through stinging hail and overpowering wind. They work nights to spend their winter days scouting surf. They are watermen on an inland sea.

articles.headline: REPORT ON IRAQ EXPOSES A DIVIDE WITHIN THE G.O.P.
articles.snippet: Bipartisan Iraq Study Group report has drawn sharp criticism from conservatives who say it was wasted effort and advocates shameful retreat, while Republican moderates in aftermath of November elections cling to report and say they hope Pres Bush ...
articles.abstract: Bipartisan Iraq Study Group report has drawn sharp criticism from conservatives who say it was wasted effort and advocates shameful retreat, while Republican moderates in aftermath of November elections cling to report and say they hope Pres Bush will adopt group's principal recommendations; divisions could make it more difficult for Republicans to coalesce on national security and avoid bitter intraparty fight going into 2008 presidential campaign; Pres Bush has not yet indicated what course he intends to pursue; photo (L)
articles.lead_paragraph: Correction Appended
articles.byline: By John M. Broder and Robin Toner

articles.headline: Trading Up to Careers in the Operating Room
articles.snippet: As with health-related occupations generally, surgical technology is expected to be a source of solid job growth in the coming decades.
articles.abstract: As with health-related occupations generally, surgical technology is expected to be a source of solid job growth in the coming decades.
articles.lead_paragraph: AFTER seven years as a secretary in the psychiatry department at Montefiore Medical Center in the Bronx, India Rouault said, she was “tired of pushing papers.” She also welcomed the prospect of earning more money.

articles.headline: Black-Market Weapon Prices Surge in Iraq Chaos
articles.snippet: As a sectarian war expands, more buyers are seeking weapons, including those that had been issued to the Iraqi Army and police.
articles.abstract: As a sectarian war expands, more buyers are seeking weapons, including those that had been issued to the Iraqi Army and police.
articles.lead_paragraph: SULAIMANIYA, Iraq, Dec. 8 — The Kurdish security contractor placed the black plastic box on the table. Inside was a new Glock 19, one of the 9-millimeter pistols that the United States issued by the tens of thousands to the Iraqi Army and police.

articles.headline: On the Run as War Crosses Another Line in Africa
articles.snippet: Foreign rebels have used the Central African Republic as a staging ground to mount attacks over its porous borders.
articles.abstract: Foreign rebels have used the Central African Republic as a staging ground to mount attacks over its porous borders.
articles.lead_paragraph: KALANDAO, Central African Republic — The rumble of engines, any engines, is the signal for the villagers here to flee, leaving behind smoldering pots of wild roots and leaves, a meager afternoon meal.

articles.headline: When Winning Feels a Lot Like Losing
articles.snippet: If you’re an investor who has filed an arbitration case against your stockbroker, you would be wise to steel yourself for an irrational and unjust outcome.
articles.abstract: If you’re an investor who has filed an arbitration case against your stockbroker, you would be wise to steel yourself for an irrational and unjust outcome.
articles.lead_paragraph: IF you’re an investor who has filed an arbitration case against your stockbroker, you would be wise to steel yourself for an irrational and unjust outcome.

articles.headline: When Winning Feels a Lot Like Losing
articles.snippet: Gretchen Morgenson column recounts disturbing case in which 86-year-old Mabel Strobel sued Morgan Stanley Dean Witter for $281,729 and won; Strobel was awarded damages of $5,000 but was ordered to pay $10,350 in fees even though arbitration panel ...
articles.abstract: Gretchen Morgenson column recounts disturbing case in which 86-year-old Mabel Strobel sued Morgan Stanley Dean Witter for $281,729 and won; Strobel was awarded damages of $5,000 but was ordered to pay $10,350 in fees even though arbitration panel found Morgan Stanley liable for her losses; Federal District Judge Roger Benitez has ordered arbitration panel to take up Strobel case again and 'make a proper damage award'; photo (M)
articles.lead_paragraph: IF you're an investor who has filed an arbitration case against your stockbroker, you would be wise to steel yourself for an irrational and unjust outcome.

articles.headline: Religion for Captive Audiences, With Taxpayers Footing the Bill
articles.snippet: A growing number of programs use tax dollars to pay for religious activities aimed at prisoners, recovering addicts, job seekers, teenagers and children.
articles.abstract: A growing number of programs use tax dollars to pay for religious activities aimed at prisoners, recovering addicts, job seekers, teenagers and children.
articles.lead_paragraph: Life was different in Unit E at the state prison outside Newton, Iowa.
articles.byline: By DIANA B. HENRIQUES and  ANDREW LEHREN

articles.headline: Poisoned by Scandal, Craving an Antidote
articles.snippet: Even the most virtuous decisions have unforeseen, often damaging, consequences, and full disclosure may create as many problems as it solves.
articles.abstract: Even the most virtuous decisions have unforeseen, often damaging, consequences, and full disclosure may create as many problems as it solves.
articles.lead_paragraph: NEAR midnight on a Friday in 2000, William E. Morgenstern, the chief executive of Rent-Way, one of the nation’s largest rent-to-own retailers, was preparing for bed when a woman called to warn him that the company he had built from scratch was about to fall apart.

articles.headline: Katrina Begets a Baby Boom by Immigrants
articles.snippet: Hundreds of babies are being born to Latino immigrant workers, legal and illegal, who flocked to New Orleans to toil on its reconstruction after Hurricane Katrina; throng of new babies in handful of operational maternity wards adds unexpected load...
articles.abstract: Hundreds of babies are being born to Latino immigrant workers, legal and illegal, who flocked to New Orleans to toil on its reconstruction after Hurricane Katrina; throng of new babies in handful of operational maternity wards adds unexpected load to decimated health infrastructure in city abandoned by many of its doctors; historically black and white city had only small Latino community and virtually no experience of illegal immigration before hurricane; expectant immigrant mothers, lacking health insurance and barred from most government assistance, can go to only handful of charitable clinics that do not question immigration status; many immigrant women are forgoing prenatal care and showing up, ready to deliver, in hospital emergency rooms, where they are required to be seen regardless of their immigration status; photos (M)
articles.lead_paragraph: Correction Appended

articles.headline: Iraqi Faults U.S. Training Effort
articles.snippet: Iraq's president criticized the United States's effort to train security forces and its plans to increase advisers to the Iraqi Army. Page A12.
articles.abstract: Iraq's president criticized the United States's effort to train security forces and its plans to increase advisers to the Iraqi Army. Page A12.
articles.lead_paragraph: Iraq's president criticized the United States's effort to train security forces and its plans to increase advisers to the Iraqi Army. Page A12.

articles.headline: Taliban and Allies Tighten Grip in North of Pakistan
articles.snippet: Taliban has created virtual mini-state in northern Pakistan, using recent peace deal with government to vastly expand training of suicide bombers and fortifying its alliance with Al Qaeda and foreign fighters; Pakistani militants are said to be op...
articles.abstract: Taliban has created virtual mini-state in northern Pakistan, using recent peace deal with government to vastly expand training of suicide bombers and fortifying its alliance with Al Qaeda and foreign fighters; Pakistani militants are said to be openly flouting terms of Sept accord, under which they agreed to end cross-border help for Taliban insurgency that revived in Afghanistan with new force this year; foreign fighters are challenging government authority in area, and also wresting control from local tribes and spreading their influence to neighboring areas; tribes offered refuge to militants when they retreated to area in 2002 after American invasion of Afghanistan, but that welcome is waning in face of killings this year of more than 100 local leaders, government sympathizers or accused 'American spies'; links among various groups date to 1980's, when Arabs, Pakistanis and other Muslims joined Afghans in fight to drive Soviet Union out of Afghanistan; Pakistani, Afghan, American and NATO officials ponder what can be done to bring region under control; photos; maps (L)
articles.lead_paragraph: Correction Appended
articles.byline: By Carlotta Gall and Ismail Khan

articles.headline: Intrigue Over Spy’s Death Spreads to Germany
articles.snippet: German authorities say they have begun criminal investigation of Russian businessman Dmitri V Kovtun after finding traces of polonium 210 around Hamburg four days before he met in London with Alexander V Litvinenko, former Russian spy who died aft...
articles.abstract: German authorities say they have begun criminal investigation of Russian businessman Dmitri V Kovtun after finding traces of polonium 210 around Hamburg four days before he met in London with Alexander V Litvinenko, former Russian spy who died after ingesting radioactive substance; announcement raises possibility that polonium was carried from Moscow to London by way of Germany; it adds to suspicions that case is connected to shadowy world of agents and businessmen, defectors, spies and exiles let loose by dissolution of KGB, and still entwined with successor agencies; case has strained relations between Russia and Britain, and has now entangled Germany; Kovtun, who had been living in Germany, has been in Moscow hospital since Dec 7, suffering from exposure to polonium; chronology of events in case recalled; photos (M)
articles.lead_paragraph: MOSCOW, Dec. 10 - The German authorities announced Sunday that they had begun a criminal investigation of a Russian businessman after finding traces of polonium 210 around Hamburg beginning on Oct. 28 -- four days before he met in London with the former Russian spy who died after ingesting the radioactive substance.
articles.byline: By Steven Lee Myers and Mark Landler

articles.headline: Taliban and Allies Tighten Grip in North of Pakistan
articles.snippet: Islamic militants are flouting a recent peace deal and fortifying alliances with Al Qaeda and foreign fighters, creating a virtual Taliban mini-state.
articles.abstract: Islamic militants are flouting a recent peace deal and fortifying alliances with Al Qaeda and foreign fighters, creating a virtual Taliban mini-state.
articles.lead_paragraph: PESHAWAR, Pakistan — Islamic militants are using a recent peace deal with the government to consolidate their hold in northern Pakistan, vastly expanding their training of suicide bombers and other recruits and fortifying alliances with Al Qaeda and foreign fighters, diplomats and intelligence officials from several nations say. The result, they say, is virtually a Taliban mini-state.
articles.byline: By Carlotta Gall and Ismail Khan

articles.headline: Katrina Begets a Baby Boom by Immigrants
articles.snippet: Babies born to workers who flocked to help rebuild New Orleans are straining its decimated health system.
articles.abstract: Babies born to workers who flocked to help rebuild New Orleans are straining its decimated health system.
articles.lead_paragraph: NEW ORLEANS — First came the storm. Then came the workers. Now comes the baby boom.

articles.headline: Squeezing Money From the Music
articles.snippet: Major labels have begun demanding a cut of concert earnings or T-shirt, ring tone and merchandise revenue from new artists seeking record contracts.
articles.abstract: Major labels have begun demanding a cut of concert earnings or T-shirt, ring tone and merchandise revenue from new artists seeking record contracts.
articles.lead_paragraph: “Konvicted,” a new CD from Akon, promised to be one of the year’s big sellers when it appeared in record stores last month. Buoyed by two of the hottest singles in the country, Akon, a silky-voiced R&B singer, even had the most-viewed page among major label acts on MySpace.com.

articles.headline: Hedging ’06: Year to Read the Caveats
articles.snippet: 2006 has been year that hedge fund investors found out that funds are not infallible; year is third straight year that global equity markets and long-only managers outperformed hedge funds; many investors remain committed to funds; more than $110 ...
articles.abstract: 2006 has been year that hedge fund investors found out that funds are not infallible; year is third straight year that global equity markets and long-only managers outperformed hedge funds; many investors remain committed to funds; more than $110 billion flooded into hedge fund industry in 2006 through third quarter, compared with $47 billion last year and record $99 billion in 2002; hedge funds are victims of their own success; more managers chasing more returns in more corners around globe means big returns are harder to come by; performances of Goldman Sachs-owned Global Alpha, which returned 40 percent in 2005 and 11 percent this year, and Atticus Global, which was up 11.5 percent in November and 32.2 percent for year, detailed; collapse of Amaranth Advisors, which made bad bets in natural gas industry, discussed (M)
articles.lead_paragraph: For Global Alpha, the $10 billion hedge fund run by Goldman Sachs, 2005 was a stellar year. By the close of the year, the fund, which manages money for some of the firm's wealthiest clients and employees, was up 40 percent after fees, a performance that helped contribute almost $600 million to Goldman's 2006 first-quarter earnings.

articles.headline: Iraq Is Failing to Spend Billions in Oil Revenues
articles.snippet: Iraq is not spending billions of dollars of oil revenues set aside to rebuild its damaged roads, schools and power stations and to repair refineries and pipelines, even as American financial support dwindles; bureaucrats are so fearful and confuse...
articles.abstract: Iraq is not spending billions of dollars of oil revenues set aside to rebuild its damaged roads, schools and power stations and to repair refineries and pipelines, even as American financial support dwindles; bureaucrats are so fearful and confused by anticorruption measures put in place by American and Iraqi governments that they are afraid to sign off on contracts; inability to spend money raises serious questions for government; it has to demonstrate to citizens who are skeptical and suspicious of government corruption that it can improve basic services, and that as American funds are being reduced it can prove to other foreign donors that it can quickly put to use money they may be willing to commit; photo (M)
articles.lead_paragraph: BAGHDAD, Dec. 10 - Iraq is failing to spend billions of dollars of oil revenues that have been set aside to rebuild its damaged roads, schools and power stations and to repair refineries and pipelines.

articles.headline: Hedging ’06: Year to Read the Caveats
articles.snippet: After a strong 2005, earnings in 2006 have shown that hedge-fund investing is hard, and no one — not even Goldman Sachs — is infallible.
articles.abstract: After a strong 2005, earnings in 2006 have shown that hedge-fund investing is hard, and no one — not even Goldman Sachs — is infallible.
articles.lead_paragraph: For Global Alpha, the $10 billion hedge fund run by Goldman Sachs, 2005 was a stellar year. By the close of the year, the fund, which manages money for some of the firm’s wealthiest clients and employees, was up 40 percent after fees, a performance that helped contribute almost $600 million to Goldman’s 2006 first-quarter earnings.

articles.headline: Not Boasting, Even Though He Could
articles.snippet: David Carr column on Washington Post chief executive Donald E Graham, who could boast about company's performance in beleaguered newspaper industry but does not; says Washington Post is now education business with newspaper adjunct; says growth of...
articles.abstract: David Carr column on Washington Post chief executive Donald E Graham, who could boast about company's performance in beleaguered newspaper industry but does not; says Washington Post is now education business with newspaper adjunct; says growth of Kaplan, test preparation company--division that lost $13 million in 2001 and had operating income of $158 million in 2005--and investments in cable and broadcast have kept company's stock from sharing some of pain of other media companies (M)
articles.lead_paragraph: Correction Appended

articles.headline: In Web Traffic Tallies, Intruders Can Say You Visited Them
articles.snippet: In order to increase the count of users of their sites, some Web publishers are automatically popping up articles, then counting the pop-up as a page view.
articles.abstract: In order to increase the count of users of their sites, some Web publishers are automatically popping up articles, then counting the pop-up as a page view.
articles.lead_paragraph: In late May, more than five million Web users vanished.

articles.headline: Augusto Pinochet, Dictator Who Ruled by Terror in Chile, Dies at 91
articles.snippet: Gen. Augusto Pinochet Ugarte became a symbol of human rights abuse and corruption.
articles.abstract: Gen. Augusto Pinochet Ugarte became a symbol of human rights abuse and corruption.
articles.lead_paragraph: Gen. Augusto Pinochet Ugarte, the brutal dictator who repressed and reshaped Chile for nearly two decades and became a notorious symbol of human rights abuse and corruption, died yesterday at the Military Hospital of Santiago. He was 91.

articles.headline: Times Sq. Ads Spread Via Tourists’ Cameras
articles.snippet: Online, an army of consumers is spreading messages from advertisers well beyond Manhattan.
articles.abstract: Online, an army of consumers is spreading messages from advertisers well beyond Manhattan.
articles.lead_paragraph: Advertisers have long been drawn to Times Square as a valuable place to reach consumers, paying hundreds of thousands of dollars for space on billboards and blazing video screens.

articles.headline: In Web Traffic Tallies, Intruders Can Say You Visited Them
articles.snippet: Nielsen/NetRatings figures show financial Web site Entrepreneurship.com had 2 million visitors in April, from 7.6 million year earlier; Entrepreneur.com visited them, and not other way around, through use of pop-up windows; pop-ups were unusual be...
articles.abstract: Nielsen/NetRatings figures show financial Web site Entrepreneurship.com had 2 million visitors in April, from 7.6 million year earlier; Entrepreneur.com visited them, and not other way around, through use of pop-up windows; pop-ups were unusual because they contained news content, making them harder to distinguish from intentional visit to Entrepreneur.com's site; technique of using pop-ups to gain readers underscores just how important sheer numbers have become in online media business; advertisers are shifting their marketing dollars to Internet, but rates they pay are low compared to traditional media; publishers who have struggled for years to find way to making money online are taking aggressive steps to get their Web pages in front of as many computer users as possible; Benjamin Edelman, doctoral candidate at Harvard who has built database to track pop-ups, says other sites that appear to have used pop-ups for content in last year include Concierge.com, Web site of Conde Nast Traveler magazine, ForbesAuto.com and Heavy.com, popular humor site; photos (L)
articles.lead_paragraph: In late May, more than five million Web users vanished.

articles.headline: Intrigue Over Spy’s Death Spreads to Germany
articles.snippet: German authorities are investigating a Russian businessman in connection with a former spy’s death after finding traces of polonium 210 in Hamburg.
articles.abstract: German authorities are investigating a Russian businessman in connection with a former spy’s death after finding traces of polonium 210 in Hamburg.
articles.lead_paragraph: MOSCOW, Dec. 10 —The German authorities announced Sunday that they had begun a criminal investigation of a Russian businessman after finding traces of polonium 210 around Hamburg that date back to Oct. 28 — four days before he met in London with the former Russian spy who died after ingesting the radioactive substance.
articles.byline: By Steven Lee Myers and Mark Landler

articles.headline: S.E.C. to Ease Auditing Standards for Small Publicly Held Companies
articles.snippet: The long-awaited interpretation of the Sarbanes-Oxley Act is the culmination of a fierce lobbying battle between accounting firms and small public companies.
articles.abstract: The long-awaited interpretation of the Sarbanes-Oxley Act is the culmination of a fierce lobbying battle between accounting firms and small public companies.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, Dec. 10 — The Securities and Exchange Commission will begin the process of easing auditing standards for thousands of smaller public companies this Wednesday when it proposes rules under the most contentious provision of the Sarbanes-Oxley Act.

articles.headline: Not Boasting, Even Though He Could
articles.snippet: Donald E. Graham’s financial engineering has allowed The Washington Post Company to remain invested in journalism in a way that few other media companies can afford.
articles.abstract: Donald E. Graham’s financial engineering has allowed The Washington Post Company to remain invested in journalism in a way that few other media companies can afford.
articles.lead_paragraph: Last Wednesday afternoon, Donald E. Graham, the chief executive of the Washington Post Company, arrived in Manhattan for the Credit Suisse media week for analysts and told them, well, not much.

articles.headline: Squeezing Money From the Music
articles.snippet: Music industry is trying to fill void from decay of compact disc sales by selling T-shirts, ring tones and downloads of recordings; industry as whole still remains uncertain and must try to promote digital sales at same time it seeks to preserve C...
articles.abstract: Music industry is trying to fill void from decay of compact disc sales by selling T-shirts, ring tones and downloads of recordings; industry as whole still remains uncertain and must try to promote digital sales at same time it seeks to preserve CD and brick-and-mortar retail shops; graph; photos (L)
articles.lead_paragraph: "Konvicted," a new CD from Akon, promised to be one of the year's big sellers when it appeared in record stores last month. Buoyed by two of the hottest singles in the country, Akon, a silky-voiced R&B singer, even had the most-viewed page among major label acts on MySpace.com.

articles.headline: Iraq Is Failing to Spend Billions in Oil Revenues
articles.snippet: The inability to spend the money set aside to rebuild damaged infrastructure raises serious questions for Iraq’s government.
articles.abstract: The inability to spend the money set aside to rebuild damaged infrastructure raises serious questions for Iraq’s government.
articles.lead_paragraph: BAGHDAD, Dec. 10 — Iraq is failing to spend billions of dollars of oil revenues that have been set aside to rebuild its damaged roads, schools and power stations and to repair refineries and pipelines.

articles.headline: Death Stirs Joy, and Violence
articles.snippet: Chileans filled Santiago streets to celebrate the death of the former dictator Gen. Augusto Pinochet, but violence marred the revelry. Page A8.
articles.abstract: Chileans filled Santiago streets to celebrate the death of the former dictator Gen. Augusto Pinochet, but violence marred the revelry. Page A8.
articles.lead_paragraph: Chileans filled Santiago streets to celebrate the death of the former dictator Gen. Augusto Pinochet, but violence marred the revelry. Page A8.

articles.headline: S.E.C. to Ease Auditing Standards for Small Publicly Held Companies
articles.snippet: Securities and Exchange Commission will begin process of easing auditing standards for thousands of smaller public companies on Dec 13 when it proposes rules under most contentious provision of Sarbanes-Oxley Act; relaxed standards represent compr...
articles.abstract: Securities and Exchange Commission will begin process of easing auditing standards for thousands of smaller public companies on Dec 13 when it proposes rules under most contentious provision of Sarbanes-Oxley Act; relaxed standards represent compromise, giving qualified victory for businesses, which had considered any regulations burdensome, and for auditing firms, which had benefited from imposition of stringent requirements on their clients; Section 404 of act requires publicly traded companies to assess controls they had put in place to ensure that their financial reports are reliable; rule was intended to try to discourage fraud and manipulation of financial statements; SEC's long-awaited interpretation of section is culmination of fierce lobbying battle, pitting largest accounting firms against equally influential coalition of small public companies, which has lobbied for years for relief; SEC chairman Christopher Cox and Public Company Accounting Oversight Board chairman Mark W Olson comment; photos (M)
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, Dec. 10 - The Securities and Exchange Commission will begin the process of easing auditing standards for thousands of smaller public companies this Wednesday when it proposes rules under the most contentious provision of the Sarbanes-Oxley Act.
